review_detail: The Lobster just loses its charm at a certain point, and nothing interesting or exciting happens with the characters.

This movie is like science fiction, except that in it, human nature is altered in some fundamental ways. If you are a romantic like me, you might find this painful to watch, but cynics might love it. I really hated this movie.
You can see what The Lobster is trying to say so clearly that there's never that refreshing possibility of misunderstanding or ambiguity, essential for a real work of genius.
The unabashed strangeness of the whole affair will mean only some audiences need apply. For me, this is easily the most original movie of the year, and it's also one of the best.
The Lobster is not for everybody. But if you're adventurous and patient, there are ample rewards to be had.
Alas, the movie loses its assurance in the over-extended second half.
Part of the joy of Lanthimos's film is seeing in it any degree of subtext you like.
Among the recent crop of dystopias, The Lobster is quite possibly unique -- an actors' workshop exercise that relies almost entirely on dialogue and situations instead of kinetic displays of heroism.
Like [Lanthimos's] other films, The Lobster invents a world all its own.
Lanthimos wrings emotion out of human interaction in ways that are both bizarre and funny.
A delightfully bleak satire set in a dystopian present.
Farrell and Weisz spark off of one another, delivering a convincing and rather touching on-screen partnership.
Hardly less kind in its satiric attack on the basic emotional pillars of human existence than Lanthimos's last two films, but it adds a veneer of magical realism.
Lanthimos makes brutal, incisive points to make about the absurdity of coupling in the first place, much less society's view of what makes a perfect couple.

Lanthimos is obviously after bigger game than a black relationship comedy, every detail (even the most horrifying) in the movie contributes to what is becoming Lanthimos' signature tone of heartbreaking hilarity.

"The Lobster" peters out about halfway through but regardless, director Lanthimos and co-writer Filippou have constructed a singular and ambitious vision, rich with symbolism and observant commentary about societal pressures to pair up.
Lanthimos invests his absurdist parable with a dark, deadpan humor and an eerie poetry....
The Lobster is brilliant, but it's bleak.
A brutal critique of the hell human relationships can be. [Full review in Spanish]
Greek director Yorgos Lanthimos may have positioned himself among the world's great, provocative "maverick" filmmakers with this bizarre yet fascinating dystopian nightmare for grown-ups.
Yorgos Lanthimos' first English-language feature is a wickedly funny, unexpectedly moving satire of couple-fixated society.
There ... dozens of astonishing and strange and funny moments of the sort that only Lanthimos can conjure.
Inordinately strange and tiresomely glum, but in spots hideously funny.
This is cinema in quotemarks, tongue-in-cheek storytelling that uses absurdity to hold a mirror to how we live and love.
Seu senso de humor absurdo constantemente surpreende o público.
Lanthimos' ability to combine arch humour and outbursts of shocking violence is as potent as ever.
Yorgos Lanthimos' The Lobster is maybe the most romantic movie of the year. Or maybe it's the most depressing. Or perhaps it's the most funny. Actually, it's all of those things.
Yorgos Lanthimos' The Lobster is maybe the most romantic movie of the year.

It took some time to digest but "The Lobster" feels full of life and is a soulful opus on love. Quirky and clever, its black comic tones shouldn't distract from its core narrative and mission; to engage the parimeters and infatuation of devotion.
The near-surgical precision with which Yorgos Lanthimos approaches the most surreal of conceits turns out to be a double-edged sword.
It's an idea with delicious social parallels ripe to be explored and, for the first half at least, that's exactly what you get.
Lanthimos presents a fully formed original vision that hits a perfect tone even when the narrative begins to get away from him a bit.
Richly rewarding but often very disturbing.
Acclaimed Greek auteur Lanthimos's English language debut is a smart, funny and disturbing allegory about the absurdity of rigid societal norms.
A poisonously effective work from an utterly singular director. You walk out feeling ever so slightly changed by it. There are few higher compliments.
A biting and idiosyncratic combination of romance, comedy, and body horror, The Lobster is one wonderful, oddball chimera of a movie.
Savagely funny and ultimately tragic.
Lanthimos has a gift for making imagined social conventions plausible and even logical, and in doing so he exposes -- in often brutal, mordantly funny fashion -- the arbitrariness of our own.

Beyond the cruel deadpan humour and icy, muted visuals is a thoughtful romantic tale set in a world where people are forbidden from marching to the beat of their own drum. The Lobster is a defiantly oddball take on the classic dystopian-future narrative.
It's a wondrously silly premise, and one that Lanthimos executes with rigorous illogic and immaculate formal control.
The Lobster is as weird and wonderful as it sounds and will make you think twice before asking the dreaded question, 'Are you still single?'

Filippou's script takes on a defiant, prickly life of its own, refusing to play as an easy allegory: this is no linear emotional journey dressed in dystopian clothes in the style of Eternal Sunshine Of The Spotless Mind.
An overlong mess.

The Lobster easily gets you involved in it's own universe to tell a story about forbiden love and a man's struggle to overcome the obstacles he has to face because of it - all of this accompanied by slow and dry humor- . [Full review in Spanish]
A very well executed scary comedy, supported by cold performances and lead by a splendid Colin Farell. [Full review in Spanish]
A very peculiar love story about love, jealousy and control, sacrifice and selfishness, where there's little room for a positive side of anything. [Full review in Spanish]
There's a wealth of bleak comedy in all of this but, having carefully laid out his thesis, Lanthimos doesn't know where to take it or what he really thinks about it.
[Lanthimos'] vision remains intact, his humour as dry and at times unfathomable as ever. He is a true original.

It's certainly one of most original films of the year, although not one of the most consistent... Lanthimos and his co-writer Efthymis Filippou​ give us a fascinating set of questions, but they do not feel the need to answer them.
For all the absurdity at play, the genius of The Lobster is its depiction of a society and world view that's unsettlingly not all that unfamiliar.
The Lobster is a bit of everything. At times it's hilarious, especially in its first half-hour or so, sometimes it's deeply disturbing and occasionally thought-provoking.
Lanthimos is an acquired taste ... This is an accessible, fun and occasionally frustrating entry into his body of work.
A brilliantly funny horror film about dating.
It all gets a bit lost in the woods, but there's enough finely honed madness in the corridors of the hotel to cover the price of a room.
The sheer verve of the filmmakers earned them the Jury Prize at Cannes, where unique and risky filmmaking is rewarded ahead of commercially satisfying fare
Yorgos Lanthimos's black comedy is entirely strange and a head-scratcher but its core message is certainly relatable to a large demographic.
The Lobster is a European arthouse film par excellence - precisely the kind of project you can't imagine ever being made in Hollywood.
It may seem like ludicrous nonsense on the surface, but what it has to say about love, fidelity and dependency is more revealing than anything Farrell wears under his kecks.
Superficially sharp but easily overcooked and with not quite enough meat to be entirely satisfying.
A film set in an alternate reality must take time to establish the rules of its particular fiction, and most of the joys of The Lobster arise from these early scenes.
Freaky-deakies need love too.
Appreciation for the sheer conceptual confidence of the film gathers momentum once you think back over it.
The Lobster is a refreshingly outstanding film in its simultaneous originality and familiarity.
Lanthimos again exhibits his aptitude for creating insular, ruthlessly regimented microcosms through which to unleash his scathing satire.
The gag may ultimately wear thin, but it's a hoot while it lasts.
To call the film weird would be an understatement, but it's the strange, surreal world and the little details that make it even stranger that are the film's best asset.
In a way, you could say THE LOBSTER is like a Woody Allen film if Woody did huge amounts of hallucinogenic drugs all through the scripting phase and principal photography.
Lanthimos trumps the outlandish premise and turns the film into accessible and timeless reverie. It's a spark of ingenuity that doesn't rely on subversions or meta humor. Just originality.
Though many elements are undeniably comedic, The Lobster belongs first and foremost to the horror genre; a fact all the more impressive considering it never seeks to deliberately scare its audience
All so weird, intriguing and occasionally amusing. Unfortunately, director Yorgos Lanthimos tries to claw out too many ideas leading The Lobster to drift and go off the boil.
An rare movie that some will enjoy with passion, but general audiences might find it too weird. [Full review in Spanish]
Easily one of the films of the year.

As expected with Lanthimos, The Lobster is utterly bizarre... it's the director's first film in English, yet also his first to show shades of human side, even as it concludes that we humans are an exceptionally silly and sad little species.

[Lanthimos] takes his sweet time in unveiling the full breadth of his film's alternate reality and its governing laws, and the world we are introduced to looks very much like our own in the present day.
Throwing a solid Hollywood cast into a surreal arthouse satire, acclaimed Greek filmmaker Yorgos Lanthimos (Dogtooth) makes his English-language debut with a bang.
When it chooses to be -- which, thankfully, is often -- the film is so funny as to induce tears. Then, on a dime, it's appallingly sad again.
It's all pretty deadpan and frequently very funny - punctuated, as is Lanthimos' wont, with brutal violence towards animals
The central issue is the inevitable paradox where you can't meet someone when you're lonely, which is when you most want to meet someone.
The dry wit and pervasively odd sensibility of The Lobster make it very worth cozying up to.
A movie that seems kind and inoffensive... but that will destroy and change your life. [Full review in Spanish]
In this movie, Lanthimos shows himself as a seasoned director. [Full review in Spanish]
Ultimately, The Lobster is fascinating, funny, but a little under-cooked.
"The Lobster" is more than a satire on the dating game. It digs deeper, needling at the status of our most tender emotions.
The picture's surrealism requires an attentive and particular audience which will find rewards therein.
A film that doesn't take itself too seriously but it has a lot of great moments thanks to its highly stylish tone. [Full review in Spanish]
This viewer appreciated 'The Lobster''s willingness to take this premise all the way, without pulling any punches.
The performances are perfect, showing the range and hability of every cast member. [Full review in Spanish]
Lanthimos' films are so laced with cruelty and despair that it can be easy to forget how fascinating and funny they are.
Even though The Lobster is full of dark humor, you won't see the characters winking at the viewer. [Full review in Spanish]

Clever and transgressive, sophisticated and intriguing, the film is a brilliant reflection on what society expects of individuals as members of a couple and the stupidity of dogmatism. [Full review in Spanish]
Like every great film it's perfectly written and it doesn't adhere itself to the conventions of the genre rising above the plot and development. [Full review in Spanish]
Colin Farrell is formidable in this film. [Full review in Spanish]
The Lobster, like the crustacean itself, is delivered in segments.
An original film, outstanding, a success. [Full review in Spanish]
The Lobster is a brilliant piece of satire, but largely fails in an attempt to build its wicked wit into a more conventional romance.
For this viewer the whole thing ran out of steam halfway through. A general flat affect, mirrored in visuals and performance, eventually stopped being funny.
Bone-dry dystopian satire, with Lanthimos piling absurdity upon absurdity, results in a film that is by turns entertaining and baffling, but also fully in command of its crazy world.
Pitched somewhere between Luis Bunuel and Larry David, Lanthimos combines small behavioural comedy and twisted surrealism with darkly cynical edge.

In this half-mythical, half-surrealistic portrait of an innocent Everyman's confrontation with a cold-blooded system, Lanthimos achieves a level of audience identification that his previous films had failed to bring about.
A film worthy of being seen (again and again) for tenderize and view with concern the way that our relations have been taking over the years. [Full Review in Spanish]
A narrative shapeshifter that gleefully toys with its audience's perception of love and themselves.
In the end, The Lobster is one of the most bizarre (and therefore original) love stories ever told in cinema, exploring deep into human psyche. [Full Review in Spanish]
This is not a movie like too many others. Or any, in fact.
"The Lobster" is very much its own brand of horror movie, as well as a deranged thought experiment, a stealth love story, and a witty dismantling of the usual barriers separating man from beast.
A boldly imaginative Kafka-esque parable, "The Lobster" is loaded with dazzling ideas that don't ultimately pull together.

Lanthimos's terrifically twisted satire takes us places most films fear to tread. The symbolism is humanized by a top-flight cast and an ending that manages to be brutal and rapturously romantic at the same time.
In its own, surreal way, it says something about modern society. Who hasn't felt pressured by parents to pair off? Or by single friends to stay unattached?
The Lobster is a droll piece of work lashed with grim humor. For every moment that makes you laugh, there may be another that leaves you with your mouth hanging open.
It's life viewed at its most pessimistic, not just to get us down but to force us, like the best absurdist works, to reexamine what we take for granted.
The existential rabbit-hole plot of The Lobster couldn't be more bonkers. The premise shouldn't work at all, but it does...and beautifully.
Almost before you know it, The Lobster has morphed into a parable about sacrifice in the name of love-all without dialing back the brutal absurdism one bit.
This movie is crazypants, but, man, it is my kind of crazy.

Mr. Farrell, a habitual over-actor, is especially affecting because you can sense his effort to restrain himself. Rachel Weisz ... is perfectly cast as the only person in this world with the normal capacities for warmth, empathy and desire.
All of this could only have come from the warped imagination of Greek filmmaker Yorgos Lanthimos, here making his singularly strange English-language debut.
A cynical sci-fi comedy about life's most clichéd script: pair off or perish. That's been the formula since the first primeval fish, and every living thing since has been a sequel.
[The film] grandiosely aims to be a dark comedy reflection of our rigid world, but it is so dark that nothing can be truly gleaned beyond its own satisfied cleverness.
[CANNES 2015] This lobster is a dog.
The Lobster is Lanthimos's first English-language film - Kinetta, Dogtooth, and Alps were all in his native Greek - but no aspect of his sensibility has been lost in translation.

Imaginatively designed but also intellectually bracing, "The Lobster" boasts a nervous unease that pulses throughout the film, lending the story an endless tension and unpredictability. We never have any idea where Lanthimos is going next.
Darkly funny, it's a perfect example of world-building. ... Set in a dystopian near future, it's the ultimate Bridget Jones nightmare: singletons are being singled out.
The English-language debut of Greek director Yorgos Lanthimos is built on a terrific premise, but some cracks appear in the foundation by the final act.
A sad, warm and genuinely touching story about... how hard it is to form a deep relationship in a society that values artificiality.
People say this kind of thing all the time - I'm pretty sure I have a time or two - but "The Lobster" is unlike any movie you've ever seen.
The Lobster packs a wicked punch, eviscerating modern romance in surprising and evocative ways.
While it starts out as a sharp satire on the horrors of dating, The Lobster stretches so far into absurdity that its various eccentricities overshadow the point it's trying to make.
Whatever its merits or intellectual pretensions, I am looking forward to never seeing it again.
If you can live with its blemishes, "The Lobster" is a bracing experience.
Perhaps nearly two hours of this world is more than necessary, but the themes and emotions presented in "The Lobster" are deeply felt, even when articulated by blank faces.
An uproarious yet deadpan satire concerning societal constructs, dating mores and power structures that also manages to be a surprisingly moving, gloriously weird love story.
Weird, confounding, amusing but perplexing - those are all words which spring to mind when trying to describe The Lobster.
[A] seriously funny horror-comedy.

Deadpan allegory without a single straight answer... Lanthimos remains one of world cinema's prime proponents of The Weird... The moments of tenderness and weirdness are the movie's highest, most Buñuelesque highs.
The Lobster's delightfully original, disturbing and peculiar opening hour just about makes up for the fact that its second half is disappointingly dull.

The Lobster is a divinely weird satire of romantic conformity from Greek filmmaker Yorgos Lanthimos. It's a recipe that's as weird as it is tragic, as philosophically sabre sharp as it is hilarious; this is a film that deserves your time.
...it plays cleverly with the compatibility assumptions behind, say, singles groups and online dating sites.
Its tone of deadpan absurdism never really develops into anything truly subversive or visionary. It's a weirdo, sub-J.G. Ballard conceit: J.G. Ballard for Dummies.

director Yorgos Lanthimos made an art house splash in 2010 with his black comedy "Dogtooth." While his latest is still dark in its outlook, it's also more laugh-out-loud funny, it's witty absurdism complemented by its deadpan acting.
A wild, sad, mordantly funny dystopia that gives sexual desperation the bad name it deserves.
Lanthimos takes our intrinsic desire for companionship, filters it through a funhouse mirror, and reflects it back to us brilliantly.
This festival favorite becomes a sometimes scary, if darkly humorous take on the future (maybe) in the hands of absurdist director Yorgos Lanthimos.
Yorgos Lanthimos has made a film that's disturbingly hilarious, and perhaps even surpasses the benchmarks for discomfort he set with 2010's Oscar-nominated Dogtooth.
While extremely funny, it is a bitter and ruthless film. Lanthimos plays target practice and his aim is deadly.
The Lobster is what would happen if Wes Anderson set about doing Franz Kafka, with a hefty dash of George Orwell thrown into the mix: surreal, comic, sad, strange, beautiful, sublime.

Investigates the nature of our need for a partner (who else will apply that pain-relief cream to the small of your back?), how we cling to superficial similarities to justify our matches, and our denial, at our peril, of our animal nature.
The best romantic satire since Eternal Sunshine of the Spotless Mind.
If we've come to idolize marriage in contemporary Western society, The Lobster has come to desecrate it.
Humor in the Craziness of the Situations
It's a murky soup of commentary and ideas about modern love and loneliness presented in the most unsettling and imaginative way.
By the 60-minute mark Lathimos' bag of tricks is empty, kickstarting a long slide into tedium that sinks a project that should have sung.
Farrell absolutely kills it as David. Weisz gives one of her best performances since her Oscar-winning turn in The Constant Gardener.
[Lanthimos'] commitment to his high-concept tragicomedies is extraordinary.

Loneliness is all-encompassing and human desperation can be disturbing: We've seen these ideas before. It just so happens that The Lobster lets them play out in the weirdest cinematic thought experiment imaginable.
This is proof that you can be uniquely offbeat and utterly boring and nonsensical, too.
Farrell makes a convincing sad sack regaining his romantic pulse. Weisz is radiant as, depending on how you see her character, a triumphant or a tragic heroine. Take a chance and go with this one.
[A]n anti-romance that presents two, extreme ways of living as a means of dissecting the concept of love, tossing its organs on the floor, and then stomping on the carcass.
The Lobster is an incredibly weird movie, but its heart is totally on its sleeve and in the right place.

Lanthimos works the premise assiduously, especially after the Farrell character escapes and joins a band of rebel singles in the woods, and though the story slows to a crawl near the end, the poker-faced dramatization of a warped world is compelling.
It takes a touch of audacity and madness to make a film like this, a screwball, absurdist tragedy that might be a little too long and contrived for some viewers' taste.
Lanthimos and Filippou keep the audience guessing about their ultimate ends right up to the final shot, and beyond.
The movie is worthwhile, thanks to a marriage of peculiar humor and thought-provoking content.
This kind of art is not on many people's wavelength, but those who connect to it will remember it 20, 30, 40 years later.
Everyone's excellent in "The Lobster," and the suffocatingly bland settings brake just short of monumental claustrophobia.
I have an appreciation for absurdist fare, but The Lobster is an overcooked comedy that loses steam about halfway through the experience.
I was caught up almost immediately in "The Lobster," a movie as prickly and difficult to approach as the title character.

The Lobster argues that the kind of pressure society places on us to find a soulmate can lead to reckless choices. But the movie gives the alternative - people who are happy being single - the same radical treatment.
Director Yorgos Lanthimos challenges society's demands that we mate - for life.
It is weird, but it is also meaningful, emotional and unexpectedly hilarious. Best of all, it's a strikingly original film, a precious thing in homogenous Hollywood.
It's a satire that's actually biting, and satirical of something not typically satirized. (Splice Today)
Strange and surreal, an audacious, absurdist satire - it's the most bizarre film I've seen!
What animal would director Lanthimos pick to be changed into? Would it be The Skunk?

The Lobster is being marketed as a comedy, and it is frequently funny, but only in the way A Clockwork Orange is frequently funny. Go and have a laugh, for sure, but don't be shocked when the claws come out.
There is much about this film that I love, and yet I can't embrace it fully. But I adore how Lanthimos creates a kind of ominous oppressiveness combined with a goofy absurdism.

"The Lobster" is a wild, fun, occasionally mean-spirited satire of the rituals and humiliations of modern dating. But it asks uncomfortable questions of us. It's the best movie I've seen so far this year.
Lanthimos doesn't deliver all the way, but he sticks his landing mightily and whets appetites for whatever he decides to do next.
If you're open to embracing a film that declines to pander to expectations, you should definitely make a date with "The Lobster."
A darkly absurdist comedy with a surprising strain of tenderness beneath its edgy surface.
The sort of movie that makes you consider what the filmmaker is saying, as well as what the movie is actually about.

Lanthimos forgoes easy sentiments about the transformative power of love; this may turn off some viewers, but there's a certain liberation and even some relief in knowing that societal pressure to settle down can be just as cruel as loneliness.
Highly original and mordantly funny. Perfect for fans of Franz Kafka, Charlie Kaufman and other bleak surrealists.
Lanthimos's unsettling tour de force reminds us of how chained to coupledom dignity remains at both the private and public level.
'The Lobster' is a different species of movie; one that takes great pains to create a world you may be hesitant to visit - but one you will definitely be happy to leave.
Interesting concept, but this vision of the future mostly involves Farrell, John C. Reilly, Rachel Weisz and the rest of cast lurching through their lines in a dull, passionless monotone.

The social pressure to be part of a couple is taken to Kafkaesque extremes in this poker-faced absurdist critique of the idea -- typically expressed most enthusiastically in commercial motion pictures -- that a successful, happy life requires a mate.
I just had no appetite for something I found under-cooked and unappealing.
... creates a fascinating world of repression and isolation, and tackles it with a deadpan sense of humor.
This one-of-a-kind film might just be the perfect date movie for people who hate dating.
The film is sort of allegorical, sort of science fiction, sort of philosophical, definitely original, definitely unpredictable and most definitely weird.
There is so much more, but part of the (perverse) pleasure of The Lobster is how it keeps you off guard, never lets you feel settled.
A brilliant and methodical consideration of strange cultural standards as they are practiced to the desensitizing peak of lunacy.
Hunger Games. Maze Runner. Divergent. This is how a dystopian movie ought to be made.
Its characters are merely single defining characteristics rather than real people; they have nothing, and hence nothing to lose. And as for wit -- without that, satire is just meanness.
Claws down, The Lobster is the weirdest movie I've seen this year.
the viewer is never allowed to feel he/she really understands what is going on. Strange ideas just keep being added to the mix.

It's a doozy of a satirical premise concocted by Yorgos Lanthimos, who directs and co-wrote the screenplay, that evokes the fundamental absurdity of the very real social pressure to find a mate and proceed along a pre-determined path of existence.
The wildest love story in many a moon.
Farrell and Weisz balance the off-kilter dystopia with vibrant, sexual heat.
Lately, it seems to always come back to John Malkovich.

Lanthimos and his co-writer, Efthymis Filippou, neatly satirize the societal pressures of mating and the difficulties of finding a soulmate, but the movie runs out of ideas long before it runs out of story.

It is a puzzler that rewards. Fans of Kafka will embrace it. The Lobster also has a little of George Orwell's 1984 and, maybe, behind all the pretense, a hint of good sense. But you've got to work to get to the good sense.
It raises more questions than it answers during its fairly tedious and ultimately rather pointless two-hour run.
It's remorseless and pure and unlike anything you've ever seen before, and it's now playing near you if you're adventurous enough to take the plunge.
It's a movie that latches on to your entertainment soul with a complexity that can't be dislodged, for better or worse.
